# Research

My research areas are macroeconomics, finance, and time series econometrics, with a focus on the estimation of forecasts and impulse response functions (IRFs), as well as the impact of expectations on business cycles. Below are selected papers that highlight my work:


- **Local Projections Are VAR Predictions of Increasing Order**  
*Revise & Resubmit, Econometrica*  
[[Download This Paper](https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/abstract_id=4882149){target="_blank"}]

- **Identification of Rational Expectations Models Under Information Frictions**  
[[Download This Paper](research/Ludwig ID of RE Models under IF.pdf){target="_blank"}]

- **Oil Prices and Inequality**  
(with [Xiaowen Lei](https://sites.google.com/site/lysfxiaowen/home){target="_blank"} and [Xiaohan Ma](https://sites.google.com/view/xiaohanma){target="_blank"})

# Teaching


I teach undergraduate and Ph.D. courses in macroeconomics and economic data analysis, with an emphasis on real-world applications, programming, and effective data communication. My courses are supported by custom-developed textbooks and materials, freely available online.


#### Textbooks


- **Economic Data Analysis**  
Available for free at [www.julianfludwig.com/eda](https://www.julianfludwig.com/eda){target="_blank"} (preliminary version). This text explains how to use software to present economic and financial data. Recommended for ECO 3363 and 3364.

- **Lecture Notes on Linear Time Series Models**  
Available for free [[here](teaching/arima.pdf){target="_blank"}]. These notes introduce linear time series models, including key tools from polynomial and linear algebra. Recommended for ECO 4306.
